title: The Cabbage Patch
source: Turkey and the Wolf - Mason Hereford & JJ Goode
categories: Turkey and the Wolf - Mason Hereford & JJ Goode
ingredients: 8cups very, very thinly sliced green cabbage (1 small head)
1small red onion, sliced into thin half-moons
¼cup fresh lime juice (from 2 to 3 limes)
2tablespoons thinly sliced lemongrass (tender insides only), from 1 large stalk
Heaping 1 cup Pig Ear Cracklins Upgrade
½cup roasted salted hulled sunflower seeds
½cup Thai or Vietnamese fried garlic
1small white onion, cut into ¼-inch pieces
2dried Thai chiles or other dried Asian red chiles, stemmed
One ½-inch piece fresh or thawed frozen galangal, peeled and finely chopped
2teaspoons gochugaru (Korean chile flakes) or other red chile flakes
directions: In a large mixing bowl, toss together the cabbage, onion, cilantro, basil, lime juice, lemongrass, jalapeño, and cracklins, breaking the cracklins up a bit if they’ve clumped while frying.
Add the dressing, toss really well, then taste and add some salt, if you want.
Put it in a serving bowl or on a platter, sprinkle with the sunflower seeds and fried garlic, and eat up.
For the Coconut-Chile Dressing:Get the oil shimmering in a small pot over medium heat. Cook the onion, garlic, Thai chiles, and galangal in there until they all soften a bit, about 5 minutes.
Add the fish sauce, sugar, shrimp paste, chile flakes, sriracha, and tamarind concentrate and cook, stirring often, until the onion is fully soft, about 10 minutes. Take it off the heat.
Stir in the coconut milk and lime juice, then pour it into your blender and blend until smooth. Let it cool fully.
It keeps in an airtight container in the fridge for up to 10 days.
